title: Ravenscraig Stadium
text:
Ravenscraig Stadium is a multi-purpose <a href="stadium">stadium</a>, in <a href="Greenock">Greenock</a>, <a href="Inverclyde">Inverclyde</a>, <a href="Scotland">Scotland</a>. The stadium is primarily set up for <a href="athletics%20%28sport%29">athletics</a>, with a running track, but it is also the traditional home of <a href="Greenock%20Juniors%20F.C.">Greenock Juniors Football Club</a>. The stadium is undergoing a £1.7 million refurbishment in preparation for the <a href="2014%20Commonwealth%20Games">2014 Commonwealth Games</a>.
The stadium was built in 1958 with a cinder track, upgraded to synthetic in 1992.
In the 1959–60 season, a capacity crowd of 8,200 watched Greenock Juniors draw 1–1 in a <a href="Scottish%20Junior%20Cup">Scottish Junior Cup</a> quarter final to <a href="Johnstone%20Burgh%20F.C.">Johnstone Burgh</a>.
In November 1972 the stadium hosted the first ever official international <a href="women%27s%20association%20football">women's football</a> match to be played in Great Britain. <a href="Scotland%20women%27s%20national%20football%20team">Scotland</a> was defeated 3–2 by <a href="England%20women%27s%20national%20football%20team">England</a>. This was almost exactly a hundred years after <a href="1872%20Scotland%20v%20England%20football%20match">the first men's international</a> between the two nations.
